The SDK is still built with source and target of version 1.7. So the built artifacts are Java 7 compatible.

This change only requires people building the SDK to use JDK 8+.
run java precommit

R: @kennknowles @lukecwik 

All of the changes are to get tests to continue to compile.
overall it's great for DDL support. One minor opinion that, can we change `LOCATION` to `TABLE_PROVIDER` directly? It may be complex to fit every source to a location path.
retest this please

@lukecwik if you build with java 8, and source=target=1.7 then you can get compiled bytecode only running on Java 8 (see the ConcurrentHashMap#keyset change for instance which will make your code compiling but broken when running on java 7 since the JVM will not be able to lookup the method at runtime). This kind of change sounds very risky and not very reliable.
Run Java PreCommit

The project already requires you to use JDK 8+ in several modules. The only real way to fix this is to force users to correctly configure their bootstrap classpath and for the bootstrap classpath to be used when releasing artifacts to ensure compatibility.
Thanks! Is it possible to add some tests for this?
I've rebased the PR, so a change to `SqlTypeUtils` should be included now.

Yeah, will continue to review once outstanding comments are addressed.

Failure seems to be related: https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PreCommit_Java_MavenInstall/15512/org.apache.beam$beam-sdks-java-io-google-cloud-platform/console

Ok then beam needs to move to toolchain asap to ensure it respects java7 constraint where it needs or just get rid of this constraint and move to java8. No other way to guarantee the bytecode compatibility otherwise cause of the few hidden breaking changes in java 8.

@jbonofre It says in the AqmpIO [javadoc](https://beam.apache.org/documentation/sdks/javadoc/2.1.0/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/amqp/package-summary.html) that it supports AMQP 1.0, don't you mean the other way around (i.e. that RabbitMQ uses 0.9.1 by default)?

Anyway I'm really looking forward for this PR to be merged and released.

Are you interested in getting some help to get the tests fixed? If so I might be able to help out. Writing embedded RabbitMQ tests can be quite tricky, but there might be a couple of workarounds:

1. Use apache qpid embedded broker and make sure that it's configured to use AMQP 0.9.x. See [this](https://stackoverflow.com/a/41552549/398441) stackoverflow answer.
1. Use something like [TestContainers](https://www.testcontainers.org/) to start RabbitMQ as a Docker container. This requires that Docker is installed on the build server though and I have no insight into this? Also the test suite will be slower since the Docker image needs to be pulled.
1. Use [embedded rabbitmq](https://github.com/AlejandroRivera/embedded-rabbitmq) which downloads an entire RabbitMQ installation when starting the test case. If Docker is not available on the build server this might be a better alternative but it'll also slow down the test significantly (at least when building from scratch) due do downloading of RabbitMQ. 

WDYT?

Sorry, I still don't understand why a `RabbitMqIO` is necessary in general, as opposed to using `AmqpIO` pointed at the RabbitMQ endpoint? Regardless of whether RabbitMQ implements AMQP 0.9.1 or 1.0, it seems like the way to support a particular version of AMQP should be to upgrade AmqpIO? @johanhaleby are you currently blocked by something that `AmqpIO` can't do?

>  it seems like the way to support a particular version of AMQP should be to upgrade AmqpIO?

Well that sounds reasonable indeed, unless there're some specific features of RabbitMQ that it cannot support?

> are you currently blocked by something that AmqpIO can't do?

To be honest I haven't even tried it, I just googled for Beam and rabbitmq support which lead me to this issue. Reading the amqp javadoc suggests that it only supports AMQP 1.0 (and for some reason I thought that was intentional), please correct me if I'm wrong. If it only supports AMQP 1.0, then I'm indeed blocked since we're using 0.9.1 in RabbitMQ. But then again, if we could make the AmqpIO support 0.9.1 then that sounds better to me.
LGTM

Looks good to me. Any set of commits is OK as long as they are each something that makes sense on their own, and is legible in the history. Also, pragmatically, the easiest unit of rollback in addition to the atomic unit of history/blame.

I agree with you, use a dedicated syntax to denote the type of table will be more extensible, how about a keyword like `type`? It's more user-friendly.
Just an update: I have been hitting OOMs killling mvn while running Kinesis tests. This will be merged.

I fixed and updated `RabbitMQIO`.

Actually, it's the opposite in term of version: `AMQPIO`Â is AMQP 1.0/1.1 version whereas `RabbitMQIO` is 0.9.

@jkff I fixed the IO and the tests. As said, AMQP IO (with usage of proton/qpid) only supports AMQP 1.0/1.1. In order to support AMQP 0.9.x (version used by RabbitMQ), we need to use the RabbitMQ client. That's the purpose of this PR (AMQP 0.9.x is very RabbitMQ specific).

@johanhaleby the tests are now OK and the IO is ready to be tested.

#4065 is merged, you can rebase now.
run java postcommit

Example failure: https://builds.apache.org/job/beam_PostCommit_Java_MavenInstall/5182/org.apache.beam$beam-runners-google-cloud-dataflow-java/testReport/org.apache.beam.sdk.io.gcp.spanner/SpannerWriteIT/testWrite/

My reading is that it is just a typo.

I am in a big +1 for only support Spark 2. The extra complexity of supporting both versions of the runner seems less valuable considering that Spark 1 has not released any fix in more than a year and most of the new things are going into version 2. Also The Big Data/Cloud distributions are already on Spark 2. So legacy Spark 1 users can just stay with Beam 2.2.0 and we can maybe add some fixes if needed there, and support the rest in the newer versions.
I'll double check & merge.
@chamikaramj Thanks for the review! Can you please take another look when you have time?
+1 for Spark2 only, although that might be better to do in beam-dev?
@chamikaramj or @rangadi Has this been merged? Is there a plan when it'll be packaged for release.
R: @kennknowles
Yeah, this was merged to HEAD. It will be included in the next release (2.3.0).
R: @robertwb wdyt?
Hi @robertwb , Can you please take a look?

OK, I think I agree that RabbitMqIO makes sense for AMQP 0-9-1 because AFAIK RabbitMQ is the only system that implements AMQP 0-9-1 (all other "generic AMQP implementations" implement AMQP 1.0) so if people need it, it's probably because they are using RabbitMQ, and in that case they'll find it easier to locate it by RabbitMqIO. I'll take a look at the PR contents soon.
